title: Archelaus (philosopher)
text:
Archelaus (; ; fl. 5th century BC) was an <a href="Ancient%20Greek%20philosophy">Ancient Greek philosopher</a>, a pupil of <a href="Anaxagoras">Anaxagoras</a>, and may have been a teacher of <a href="Socrates">Socrates</a>. He asserted that the principle of <a href="Motion%20%28physics%29">motion</a> was the separation of hot from cold, from which he endeavoured to explain the formation of the <a href="Earth">Earth</a> and the creation of <a href="animal">animal</a>s and <a href="human">human</a>s.
Life.
Archelaus was a <a href="Philosophy">philosopher</a> of the <a href="Ionian%20School%20%28philosophy%29">Ionian School</a>, called "Physicus" from having been the first to teach <a href="natural%20philosophy">natural philosophy</a> at <a href="Athens">Athens</a>. This statement of <a href="Diogenes%20La%C3%ABrtius">Diogenes Laërtius</a>, is contradicted by <a href="Clement%20of%20Alexandria">Clement of Alexandria</a>, but the two may be reconciled by supposing that Archelaus was the first Athenian who did so. According to <a href="Simplicius%20of%20Cilicia">Simplicius</a>, who probably got his information from <a href="Theophrastus">Theophrastus</a>, Archelaus was a native of <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, even though Diogenes Laërtius says it is unclear if he was born in <a href="Athens">Athens</a> or <a href="Miletus">Miletus</a>. He was the son of Apollodorus, or as some say, of Mydon, Midon, or Myson; was a pupil of <a href="Anaxagoras">Anaxagoras</a>; and is said to have taught at <a href="Lampsacus">Lampsacus</a> before he established himself at <a href="Athens">Athens</a>. He is commonly reported to have taught <a href="Socrates">Socrates</a> and <a href="Euripides">Euripides</a>. If he was the instructor of Socrates, he is never mentioned by <a href="Xenophon">Xenophon</a>, <a href="Plato">Plato</a>, or <a href="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, and this story may have been an attempt to connect Socrates with the Ionian School. However, Diogenes Laërtius does report, on the authority of <a href="Ion%20of%20Chios">Ion of Chios</a>, a contemporary of Socrates, that Socrates went with Archelaus on a trip to Samos. Also, some scholars have seen in Socrates' "autobiographical" sketch in Plato's "<a href="Phaedo">Phaedo</a>" a reference to Archelaus' theory about the generation and nourishment of the first animals. The tradition which connects Archelaus with Euripides may have arisen from a confusion with Euripides' patron, <a href="Archelaus%20I%20of%20Macedon">Archelaus I</a>, king of <a href="Macedon">Macedon</a>ia.
Philosophy.
No fragments of Archelaus have survived; his doctrines have to be extracted from <a href="Diogenes%20La%C3%ABrtius">Diogenes Laërtius</a>, <a href="Simplicius%20of%20Cilicia">Simplicius</a>, <a href="Pseudo-Plutarch">Pseudo-Plutarch</a>, and <a href="Hippolytus%20of%20Rome">Hippolytus</a>.
Archelaus held that air and infinity are the principle of all things, by which Pseudo-Plutarch supposes that he meant infinite air; and we are told, that by this statement he intended to exclude Mind from the creation of the world. If so, he abandoned the doctrine of <a href="Anaxagoras">Anaxagoras</a> at its most important point; and it seems safer to conclude that while he wished to teach the materialist notion that the mind is formed of air, he still held infinite Mind to be the cause of all things. This explanation has the advantage of agreeing with <a href="Simplicius%20of%20Cilicia">Simplicius</a>.
Beginning with primitive Matter, (identical with air mingled with Mind), by a process of thickening and thinning, arose cold and warmth, or water and fire, the one passive, the other active. Archelaus deduced motion from the opposition of heat and cold, caused by the will of the material Mind. This opposition separated fire and water, and produced a slimy mass of earth. While the earth was hardening, the action of heat upon its moisture gave birth to animals, which at first were nourished by the mud from which they sprang, and gradually acquired the power of propagating their species. Humans also appear, at first in lower forms. All these animals were endowed with mind, but humans separated from the others, and established laws and societies. It was just from this point of his physical theory that he seems to have passed into ethical speculation, by the proposition, that right and wrong are "not by nature but by custom" ()—dogma possibly suggested to him by the contemporary <a href="Sophists">Sophists</a>.
Of the other doctrines of Archelaus, he asserted that the Earth was flat, but that the surface must be depressed towards the centre; for if it were absolutely level, the sun would rise and set everywhere at the same time. He also said that the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> was the largest of the <a href="star">star</a>s. He accounted for <a href="Speech%20communication">speech</a> by the motion of the <a href="air">air</a>; for this, he seems to have adopted the views of Anaxagoras.
